I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Public–Private Partnership Support Project.1 
 
2.  The project2 will support the Government of Viet Nam’s initiatives to develop bankable 
and commercially viable public–private partnership (PPP) projects, and to promote a more 
conducive environment for PPP and utilize PPP as a catalyst for broader sector reforms. Under 
the project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide funding for the establishment and 
operation of a project development facility (PDF) as a funding mechanism to support PPP 
project preparation activities, which will include the preparation of prefeasibility studies, detailed 
feasibility studies, and bid and contract documentation. The ADB loan will be used to fund the 
proposed PDF, with specific actions that will be linked to the project loan via specific assurances 
and precedent conditions for loan disbursement.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Economic growth and demand for infrastructure. Viet Nam’s impressive economic 
growth in 2002–2012 has brought about substantial progress and development opportunities as 
well as challenges. Industrialization and urbanization rates, which are high even by Asian 
standards,  are  driving  intense  demands  for  new  and  improved  infrastructure  and  related 
services.  Infrastructure  investments,  comprising  about  10%  of  Viet  Nam’s  annual  gross 
domestic product, is mostly either state-led or, to a lesser extent, through official development 
assistance (ODA).3 However, these investments are widely acknowledged as insufficient to 
meet Viet Nam’s huge infrastructure funding needs, which are estimated at $160 billion over the 
period 2013–2022. The unmet demand has serious consequences for the country’s productivity 
and the efficiency of the economy, and in ensuring sustainable economic growth, reducing 
poverty, and meeting Millennium Development Goal targets. 
 
4.  Limited private sector investment in Viet Nam’s infrastructure development. There 
is  a  growing  recognition  of  the  increasing  importance  of  the  role  of  the  private  sector  in 
development.  However,  for  an  economy  the  size  of  Viet  Nam's,  private  investment  in 
infrastructure has been very limited.4 In this regard, promotion and leveraging of both domestic 
and foreign private sector investment in infrastructure would be best served through PPPs. PPP 
is also viewed as a means to improve efficiency and service delivery to citizens and gain access 
to new capital, expertise, and technology. The government’s Socio-Economic Development 
Plan (SEDP), 2011–2015, clearly cites the importance of establishing policies to attract private 
sector investment in infrastructure by means of PPP in line with international best practice.5 The 
SEDP  also  cites  PPP  as  an  effective  mechanism  to  address  the  limited  state  budget  for 
infrastructure projects and as a priority modality for private sector investment in infrastructure. 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the concept note for the proposed loan 16 May 2011 and provided 
small-scale technical assistance. 
3  There is a concern about the possibility of reduced access to ODA as Viet Nam has become a middle-income 
country, and this concern strengthens the government’s resolve to further engage in PPP. 
4  For further information on PPP issues in Viet Nam and a dialogue with the government on PPP, see Sector 
Assessment: Public–Private Partnerships (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
5  This is also fundamentally supported in Viet Nam’s new Socio-Economic Development Strategy for 2011–2020 
approved by the 11th Party Congress in January 2011, which emphasizes the need to accelerate the reforms of 
economic institutions, and to address infrastructure bottlenecks as two of the three “breakthroughs” the country 
needs to achieve in ensuring its continuing rapid socioeconomic development.

2 
This is echoed in ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2012–2015, whereby PPP will remain an 
important policy priority in promoting inclusive economic growth as envisaged under ADB’s 
Strategy 2020.6 The development of PPP in Viet Nam will provide opportunities for private 
sector operations. 
 
5.  Need for an appropriate public–private partnership framework. It is recognized that, 
despite concerted efforts of not only ADB but also many other development partners to promote 
the concept of PPP through numerous advocacy and training activities,7 very few actual PPP 
transactions have occurred so far beyond the energy sector. This is an indication that the 
business environment is not conducive for PPP, as it faces various constraints that make public 
sector officials unaware of the importance of PPP and the private sector less attracted to 
engage  in  such  partnerships.  This  is  exacerbated  by  the  lack  of  a  legal  and  regulatory 
framework conducive for PPP implementation, the lack of capacity to manage PPP processes 
and information, as well as the private sector’s limited access to financial resources and project 
finance skills. 
 
6.  Systemic issues. In the Viet Nam context, PPP faces systemic issues that need to be 
addressed. First, there are difficulties in creating bankable projects for PPP given uncertainties 
in the government commitment to address (i) the underlying issues of low tariffs and willingness-
to-pay (particularly in the transport and water supply sectors), (ii) perceived risks of investing in 
infrastructure projects, and (iii) lengthy government procedures. Second, there is the issue of 
the absence of government viability gap funding to support PPP projects that have strong 
economic returns but may not be commercially viable, as well as an absence of clarity on the 
other  forms  of  government  undertakings  such  as  guarantees,  making  land  available,  and 
enabling access to ODA grants to identify bankable projects. The third issue is the lack of a 
“level playing field,” particularly with respect to concerns regarding bid transparency and state-
owned  enterprise  access  to  state-directed  and/or  preferential  financing,  which  creates  a 
“crowding out” effect for private firms. The fourth and last issue is the lack of availability of long-
term debt for private sector projects, particularly in the local currency. 
 
7.  Lack  of  adequate  cost  recovery. Uncertainties in the government commitment to 
address the underlying issues of low tariffs (willingness-to-charge) and willingness-to-pay are 
prevalent, particularly in priority sectors such as transport, energy, and water supply. Low tariffs 
for produced outputs results in inadequate cash flow to support the revenue stream needed by 
investors producing these outputs. Furthermore, the private sector is deterred by perceived risks 
of investing in infrastructure projects and lengthy government procedures.  
 
8.  Support for projects that are commercially not viable but otherwise show strong 
economic returns. Given the strong demand for infrastructure in Viet Nam and private sector 
interest to invest, there is a need to explore financing options critical to securing bankable PPP 
projects with potentially strong economic returns. However, this may not be commercially viable 
in the absence of clarity on various forms of government undertakings such as guarantees, 
viability gap funding, making land available, and enabling access to ODA grants to identify 
bankable projects. Filling in this gap is crucial to effective and successful PPP.  
                                                
6  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Viet Nam, 2012–2015. Manila; ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-
Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. Manila. 
7  The World Bank provided technical support for the establishment of a legal framework for PPP, the output of which 
was decision 71 (regulation for pilot PPP projects) and decree 78 (regulation on build-operate-transfer, build-
transfer-operate, and Build-Transfer contracts). The United States Agency for International Development (USAID), 
through its Vietnam Competitiveness Initiative, has provided the layout for the PPP road map for the Ministry of 
Planning and Investment (MPI).

3 
9.  Lack of a “level playing field.” While the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) is 
committed to ensuring that state-owned enterprises compete on a level playing field for PPP 
opportunities, there are still private sector concerns regarding bid transparency and state-owned 
enterprise access to state-directed and/or preferential financing, which creates the “crowding 
out” effect for private firms. The government will need to demonstrate greater political will to 
provide greater assurance to the private sector, and will need to continue its reform efforts and 
improved corporate governance.  
 
10.  Limited  domestic  financing  modalities  and  private  sector  access  to  financial 
resources. The financial sector in Viet Nam is relatively underdeveloped and unable to provide 
sufficient long-term capital needed by investors. Foreign banks are the most reliable source of 
medium- to long-term lending. For foreign-denominated debt, lenders are looking for credit 
enhancements and guarantee mechanisms, e.g., through export credit agencies. With limited 
resources for domestic financial institutions to meet the infrastructure funding requirements, 
concerted  reforms  are  needed  to  mobilize  domestic  resources  of  this  magnitude.  The 
government  needs  to  facilitate  the  development  of  local  capital  markets  by  (i)  enabling 
insurance firms and pension funds to finance infrastructure, (ii) deepening the bond market, (iii) 
establishing credit rating, and (iv) establishing dedicated infrastructure funds.  
 
11.  Institutional and capacity issues. Lack of government capacity to prepare quality 
feasibility studies, carry out effective competitive tender processes, and effectively deal with 
private sector transactions are also constraining factors on effective PPP.  
 
12.  Public–private partnership legal framework still needs to be made operational. In 
November 2010, the government issued decision 71/2010, as issued by the prime minister, to 
enable piloting of solicited PPP transactions on a competitive basis and raise capital from 
domestic and international sources without increasing public debt.8 Furthermore, in March 2012 
the  MPI  minister  issued  decision  392  that  established  a  PPP  office  in  the  MPI’s  Public 
Procurement Agency, and in April 2012 decision 135 outlined the functions of the PPP office. 
However, detailed implementing guidelines under decision 71 are still lacking and the specifics 
of the relationship of the PPP office with the line ministries for PPP still need to be worked out.  
 
13.  Need  for  effective  project  preparation  and  project  development  facility. Sound 
project  preparation  is  the  key  requirement  to develop  bankable  PPP  projects  that  can  be 
brought to the marketplace and to build investor confidence. Project preparation involves the 
following activities: (i) prefeasibility studies to identify candidate PPP infrastructure projects; 
(ii) preparation  of  detailed  feasibility  studies,  technical  and  engineering  specifications, 
environmental and social impact assessment with management plans, financial analysis, risk 
assessment and mitigation, and assessment of the PPP legal framework; and (iii) bid and 
contract documentation. The detailed project preparation process to be covered under activity 
(ii) and the bidding process stated in activity (iii) are aimed to help develop bankable structures 
that will provide the necessary comfort to both the private sector as well as the prospective 
lenders  to  the  project  through  appropriate  risk  allocation.  Improvement  in  the  capacity  to 
develop  bankable  projects  is  also  important  to  increasing  the  pace  of  investment  in 
infrastructure. To facilitate project development for PPPs, a PDF is required. The PDF would 
                                                
8  Decision 71 is intended to apply to pilot projects over a 3- to 5-year period, at which time it is expected that they will 
be replaced by a more comprehensive PPP Law to enable replication of a new model of PPP project formulation 
and contracting based on the current piloting initiative. Decision 71 is based on a long-term policy dialogue 
between the government and development partners and incorporates recommendations and comments of ADB, 
AFD, Japan International Cooperation Agency, KfW, Korea Eximbank, and the World Bank on several drafts of the 
regulations that were also supported by USAID.

4 
provide  the  sponsoring  government  agencies  with  the  funding  to  procure  the  necessary 
consultancy and expert services for provision of the outlined project preparation activities.  
 
14.  Lessons. From ADB experience, the key lessons learned to ensure successful PPPs 
are that there needs to be (i) government engagement on broad-based reforms and ensuring a 
level playing field for private sector participation; (ii) strong political commitment on the part of 
senior government officials to promote and advance PPPs; (iii) strong institutional support for 
planning and carrying out effective PPP project preparation, including a thorough value-for-
money analysis;9 (iv) a streamlined procurement process and institutional capacity to implement 
the  process;  (v) pooling  of  donor  resources  to  achieve  critical  mass  and  consistency  in 
approach; and (vi) sufficient financing support to include, but not be limited to, mechanisms for 
government to provide multiyear commitments, creditworthy support, and prudent management 
of the fiscal obligations created by PPPs.10  
 
15.  Public–Private Partnership Support Project. The proposed project seeks to address 
the  issue  of  creating  bankable  and  commercially  viable  PPP  projects,  while  continuing  to 
engage the government in a policy dialogue to address the PPP issues (para. 4–13). The 
government will address these issues over time as it implements actual projects. Under the 
proposed  project,  ADB  will  use  the  project  loan  modality  to  fund  the  PDF  as  a  funding 
mechanism to support project preparation activities, with specific actions that will be linked to 
the loan via specific assurances, and precedent conditions for loan disbursement.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
16.  The impact will be increased private sector investment in infrastructure. This will in turn 
improve the efficiency and quality of infrastructure services and accelerate Viet Nam’s economic 
growth.  The  outcome  will  be  an  improved  government  capacity  to  catalyze  PPPs  and 
infrastructure investments.  
 
C.  Outputs 
 
17.  The overall project design is fully in line with Viet Nam’s Socio-Economic Development 
Strategy 2011–2020, SEDP 2011–2015, and the government’s infrastructure reform agenda. 
The project will have two outputs, which are described in paras. 18–19 and illustrated in Figure 
1.  The  project’s  activities  are  consistent  with  those  outlined  in  pillars  1–3  of  ADB’s  PPP 
operational plan.11 
 
18.  Output  1:  Institutional  mechanism  for  developing  bankable  public–private 
partnership projects. The project will develop and prepare PPP pilot projects that are ready to 
be bid out to test the limitations of the existing regulatory framework for PPP, and further fine-
tune the framework. Following this, the project will support the development of a pipeline of 
economically viable bankable projects. This will be made possible through the establishment of 
the PDF that will fund the preparation of well-structured project transactions resulting in sound 
model  infrastructure  projects  that  can  be  replicated.  To  sustain  the  PDF,  mechanisms, 
procedures, and guidelines will be developed to enable reimbursement to the PDF by projects 
that are commercially viable and successfully bid out. 
                                                
9  ADB. Special Evaluation Study on ADB Assistance for Public–Private Partnerships in Infrastructure Development. 
2009. Manila. 
10  This discussion incorporates ADB experience in India, Indonesia, and the Philippines where ADB has supported 
the establishment of PDFs. In particular, the PDFs in India and the Philippines have been able to generate 
significant deal flow for their project pipeline. 
11  ADB. 2012. Public–Private Partnership Operational Plan, 2012–2020. Manila.

5 
19.  Output  2:  Strengthened  public–private  partnership  enabling  framework  and 
improved institutional capacity for public–private partnership. Although the government 
has issued decision 71 to regulate pilot investments under PPP to enable the private sector to 
engage in PPP and execute and deliver PPP transactions, as well as decisions 392 and 135 to 
establish a PPP office with specified functions, further work is required for the decisions to 
become operational. Given imperfections in the current legal and regulatory framework, the PPP 
pilot projects will identify bottlenecks in the design, implementation, and delivery of PPP projects. 
The deliverables in this output category to strengthen the enabling framework will include (i) 
proposed regulations and guidelines to tender PPP projects under international competitive 
bidding including gender assessment, (ii) review of sector laws and regulations related to PPP 
with recommendations for sector reforms, and (iii) review of the role of state-owned enterprises 
in PPP transactions and unsolicited proposals and ensuring that PPP projects tendered by an 
authorized state agency preclude any state-owned enterprise owned by such agency from 
bidding for the project.  
 
20.  To be able to fully execute and deliver PPP projects, the government will need to 
acquire the capacity to mainstream PPP processes for broader political consensus on PPP and 
develop standardized PPP processes and models for implementation by the central government 
and/or provincial and/or local governments. The project will support the government to develop 
and implement a medium-term plan for PPP capacity building that will cover specialized training 
courses on PPP and development and dissemination of toolkits reflecting international practices. 
Continued medium-term institutional capacity building to implement and sustain PPPs will be 
supported through technical assistance from other donor agencies and government budgetary 
allocations outside of the project.

22.  The Government of Viet Nam has requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to 
SDR13,171,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will 
have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions 
set forth in the draft loan agreement. The project will use the loan to support the operation of the 
PDF as an institutional funding mechanism for developing bankable PPP projects. Taxes and 
duties (on consultant services) will be financed from the ADB loan proceeds.

PDF establishment and operation costs, and institutional capacity building on PPP. The project

24.  Although  institutional  capacity  building  on  PPP  will  be  funded  by  the  government’s 
funding contribution under the project, it should be noted that the consulting services funded by 
ADB loans will also have an inherent capacity building component, via a learning-by-doing 
approach.14 The MPI and the sponsoring line ministries will build capacity as they implement 
actual PPP projects with the support of consultants funded by the loans.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
25.   The MPI will be the executing agency in collaboration with the PPP task force and other 
government ministries and agencies involved with PPP. The task force, chaired by the MPI and 
comprising the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Industry and Trade, Ministry 
of Transport, Ministry of Construction, State Bank of Viet Nam, and other relevant agencies as 
members, was established in mid-January 2011 to provide overall guidance to the government’s 
PPP piloting initiative. The task force is presently being restructured to facilitate more senior 
representation of the ministries on the task force to enable it to function more effectively as an 
interministerial coordination body for PPP. The task force will have high-level oversight of the 
PDF and will be the mechanism for coordination of line ministries on the use of the PDF. A 
dedicated project management unit (PMU) will be established with assigned staff from the PPP 
office of the MPI for day-to-day management of the PDF under the project. The PMU will be 
supported by a team of national and international experts on PPP who will be funded by the 
project.  
 
26.  ADB will coordinate with other development partners who have PPP initiatives in Viet 
Nam, including (i) Agence Française de Développement (AFD), which is processing a loan to 
fund the PDF’s operations, and is also processing grant funding of €600,000 for capacity 
building of PPP; (ii) the United States Agency for International Development (USAID)-funded 
Vietnam Competitiveness Initiative, which has provided consultants to the PPP task force and is 
supporting the MPI in conducting an initial project screening of potential PPP projects; and (iii) 
the Department for International Development of the United Kingdom, which is also considering 
grant funding to the government for PPP capacity building.  
 
27.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and detailed in the project 
administration  manual.15 A  diagram  of  the  PPP  institutional  structure  in  the  MPI  and  the 
proposed PDF fund flow mechanism are provided.16

established. In Viet Nam, decision 71 provides a broad framework for PPP but still lacks detailed implementing 
rules and regulations for implementing PPP, particularly at the sector level.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Fiduciary 
 
28.  The government’s public financial management reforms are at an early stage but steady 
progress is being made in improving the legislative and institutional framework. The National 
Assembly promulgated the Law on Public Debt Management in June 2009. The law provides a 
legal framework for a modern debt management system to monitor public debt, analyze its 
profile, and resolve and manage related fiscal risks. Implementation of the 2002 Budget Law is 
progressing. Proposed revisions to the law aim to (i) introduce a medium-term expenditure 
framework  and  performance-based  budgeting;  (ii)  improve  budget  execution;  (iii)  enhance 
budget  supervision,  monitoring,  and  implementation;  and  (iv)  increase  decentralization  of 
budget management. A new integrated computerized financial management system (treasury 
and budget management information system) was rolled out in 2008 to strengthen expenditure 
management and control. An updated and improved chart of accounts was developed. A plan 
for adoption of international public sector accounting standards was approved to provide the 
basis for preparing government financial statements that are more in line with international 
practices.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
29.  As the PDF will not finance any investments in project implementation and will aim to 
support  only  the  preparation  of  feasibility  studies,  business  case  development,  transaction 
advisory services, and PPP procurement up to the signing of the PPP contractual agreement, it 
will not require any economic and financial analysis.

9 
C.  Governance 
 
30.   With  the  high  stakes  involved  in  large  infrastructure  projects  in  several  sectors, 
challenges remain, particularly the presence of weak governance and oversight ability in dealing 
with  PPP  issues,  as  well  as  the  threat  posed  by  collusion  and  corruption.  Although  the 
government has issued a PPP regulation, there are still risks of misallocation of scarce public 
resources,  leading  to  (i)  cases  where  less-qualified  consultants  and  concessionaires  are 
awarded  contracts,  resulting  in  poorly  designed  projects;  and  (ii)  directly  negotiated  PPP 
projects or unsolicited bids where the interests of the government are discounted and the 
government bears a disproportionate share of the project risk. However, the government is 
taking an active approach against corruption, and recently adopted several legal changes, 
including the Anti-Corruption Law, 2005. Results of investigations against corruption overseen 
by  the  government  inspectorate  have  been  disclosed,  and  a  legal  framework  has  been 
established to protect and reward people who speak out against corruption.  
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
31.   The project aims to improve the investment climate and thereby contribute indirectly 
over the long term to poverty reduction, through greater access to markets and economic and 
employment opportunities, among other things. The model PPPs to be pursued under the 
project will help in direct job creation. The following actions will be undertaken to mainstream 
gender at the PDF and PPP project levels: (i) gender assessments will be undertaken in every 
project to ensure that gender issues are integrated and that project benefits are maximized for 
women  and  men;  (ii)  PPP  implementing  guidelines  will  include  guidelines  for  undertaking 
gender  analysis  and  developing  gender  action  plans;  (iii)  a  social  and  gender  specialist 
consultant will be recruited at the PDF level to ensure due diligence on gender; (iv) the design 
for individual projects will include a social and gender specialist on the project team; (v) the 
medium-term capacity development plan will include gender briefing and training sessions for 
staff of the PPP office, MPI, and sector agencies; (vi) all staff at the PPP office and PMU and 
relevant staff of sector agencies will be trained on gender issues and gender assessments, and 
women’s participation will be encouraged; and (vii) mitigation measures and other social risks 
will address gender concerns. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
32.   The  project  is  classified  category  C  for  impacts  on  the  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous peoples. 
 
33.  As the PDF will not finance any investments in project implementation and will aim to 
support  only  the  preparation  of  feasibility  studies,  business  case  development,  transaction 
advisory services, and PPP procurement up to the signing of the PPP contractual agreement, it 
will not be subject to ADB’s environmental and social safeguard requirements as prescribed in 
the  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  as  well  as  development  partner  and  government 
regulations and procedures. Gender assessment will not occur at the PDF level, but is proposed 
to be part of the project preparation activities for each PPP project.

IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
35.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the project 
administration manual and loan documents. 
 
36.  The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are 
set forth in the loan agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
37.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR13,171,000 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Public–
Private Partnership Support Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest 
charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; 
for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions 
as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to 
the Board.
